characters: YOU'RE NOT GOOD ENOUGH TO WIPE THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, one-man operation. There’s a house, a few outbuildings, corrals and a barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angle on JIM CROWLEY, a hard-working dairy farmer, 50's, dressed in coveralls. He’s opening a gate. DAIRY COWS com plodding through and head straight towards the milking ba They know the routine.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Morning, Girls. Let’s move along now, sun’s been up for an hour. Jim moves off and doesn’t see the last cow. Her name is DELILA and she looks like all the rest, except she’s walk backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim making his rounds, moving past the cows in their stal a quaint wooden sign over each: SWEET SUE, OL’ BESS, MAGG MAY, etc. The cows are facing away from us, udders attach by clear plastic hoses to a complicated milking apparatus can hear the automated pumps shushing rhythmically, see t milk coursing through the hoses. Jim reaches Delila. She’s completely still, her milk stuttering through the hose.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You okay, Delila? Suddenly, Delila turns her head, looks at him, a malevole glint in her eyes. She GROWLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim’s wife, ELLEN, hanging clothes on a clothesline. She hears Jim yelling, then sees him stumbling out of the bar scared cows running past him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh my heavens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Ellen have the door open a bit and they’re peekin in. We hear Delila’s rabid BELLOWING intermixed with CRASHING and CLANGING. Apparently, she’s wrecking the pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it’s not anthrax or hoof and mouth. I’ve never seen anything like this in 35 years of dairy farming. Ellen wants to say something, is too afraid.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: This is not natural, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Not natural? What’s that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Look at her eyes. Angle on Delila, panting, glaring at them, eyes like molt orbs, a burgeoning, unnatural fury inside her.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I’ve only seen that look one other time. Remember my cousin, Thalia?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Aww Ellen --

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Thalia was possessed, Jim. A demon took hold of that poor woman’s body and drove her right out of her mind!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Cow’s don’t get possessed, Ellen. They’re cows. They hear a BELLOW that’s more like a scream. Delila is galloping right at them, her face distorted into a snarl, ears back, teeth bared like a dog. In a panic, they slam door shut as Delila rams into it, splintering the wood. J looks at Ellen, realizes she may be right.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: My God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSH KEELING at the wheel, drinking a chocolate milk with straw. He’s mid-30'’s, casually dressed, attractive, a re guy. Music begins, the Talking Heads sing the arrestingly weird, “Once In A Lifetime” over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh drives through a typical LA suburb, intercut with sc of ordinary people doing ordinary things; walking their d playing tennis, having coffee at Starbucks, talking on th cells. The scenes are so ordinary they’re almost surreal.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Somebody once said, the only normal people are the ones you don’t know very well, and how many people do you know that well? I mean really. Your family, your friends, the people you see everyday? Oh sure, they look normal, but believe me when I tell you, normal can disguise the weirdest stuff you can imagine. The montage ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, nondescript commercial building, “Paranormal Consultants Inc” stenciled discreetly on the door.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I believe all paranormal mysteries have a scientific explanation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A combination office/lab. COLLIN CLARK in the lab area. 20's, white, geeky, chip on his shoulder. He’s repairing homemade device called THE M-PAC. It looks like a cross between an assault pistol and an ionic blow dryer.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: ».-and technology will be the key to unlocking them. Angle on ATHENA ORTIZ; Latina, 20’s, street edge, hot but on purpose. She’s at the reception desk reading a book.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Some things will always be mysteries, Collin. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ATHENA (cont'd) The most you can do is harness their energy and use them for good.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: (scoffs) Is that like the Witch’s Hippocratic Oath?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I’m a bruja.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: My mistake. A bruja.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Runs in the family. My grandmother’s a bruja too. In the barrio she’s famous.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Yes, really. I’ve seen her do amazing things and she doesn’t need any technology made from stuff you can get at Radio Shack. Stung, Collin starts to retort but Josh enters with a BAG DONUTS.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Morning, Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (off the bag) Apple fritter?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Maybe some other time, like when I’m skinny and have a dental plan. (then) Messages. A Mr. Markett called. He thinks his wife was a victim of spontaneous combustion and he’d like you to investigate and The New Age Society wants you to submit a paper on The Taos Hum Phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Screen Mr. Markett, see if he really had a wife and I don’t have time to submit a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We also have that consultation with Jim Crowley, the dairy farmer? We should leave soon. Josh crosses to Collin.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Apple fritter?

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: The new girl is not working out.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I think she’s doing great.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: She claims to be a witch, a bruja no less.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I know, Collin, and could we keep an open mind? New angle. The phone RINGS, Athena answers.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: PCI. (then) Josh, it’s Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’ll take it in my office. INT. JOSH’S OFFICE/PCI -- SAME A cramped jumble of files, tapes, books, maps and photos, Josh picking up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Colonial, God, that’s so eighties..is that olive? No, it’s more like a moss...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Honey? What are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. KITCHEN/JOSH’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS BARBARA, Josh's wife; 30'S, attractive, suburban prim. Sh looking out of the window, watching the house next door. delivery truck is in the driveway, workmen toting a new living room set (the subject of her comments) into the ho  TED STROUD and his wife, LASANDRA, supervising. They’re attractive, black, 30's.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Ted and LaSandra, our new neighbors? I invited them over for lunch tomorrow. They seem nice enough. Barbara waves at the Strouds, they wave back. As the dialogue continues Barb takes dishes out of the dishwashe and wipes off spots only she can see.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Is that why you called?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with the Vice Principal. Danni skipped school.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She did?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: It’s the new boyfriend. Cal. He’s taking advantage of her. Athena appears in Josh’s doorway, gestures, let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’ve got to go. We’ll talk about it later. They hang up but we stay with Barbara _in the kitchen. enters. 7 years old, a smart kid trying to figure out world works.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: I finished cleaning my room, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Really? Why don’t we have a look? INT. ADAM'S ROOM/JOSH’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER The room is very clean but Barbara is inspecting with scrutiny of a Marine sergeant, Adam watching, tense.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Good job, Adam. (then) Don’t you just feel better when everything is the way it’s supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Sure. I guess.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: how the the  Barbara notices the bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Adam, didn’t we say you would alphabetize your books?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: A MINUTE LATER
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam examining a 20 PAGE, HANDWRITTEN CONTRAC titled “MY CONTRACT WITH MOM BY ADAM KEELING”.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Here, Section B, item 7a. (reads) “I will put my books away in alphabetical order.”

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: But they look neat and everything.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You agreed to the contract, Adam. See? There’s your signature.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: But you said I had to sign it or I wouldn’t get my allowance.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Give and take, sweetheart. We negotiated. On Adam, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rural road. Josh driving, Athena riding shotgun. Through rear window, we can see Collin following them in a PANEL

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’m not sure if Athena’s a bruja or not but I liked what she said in her interview.

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Athena interviewing with Josh.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: My whole life I knew I was special but I didn’t know how or why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barrio. Athena hanging with her rowdy HOME GIRLS, drinking and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I was cool with that. Lots of people are ordinary, right? INT. (FLASHBACK) LIVING ROOM/GRANDMOTHER’S HOUSE -- DAY Athena’s GRANDMOTHER, gripping Athena by the shoulders, imploring her, impassioned, her eyes ablaze.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But one day my grandmother called me over to her house and told me that I was a bruja like her and that if I didn’t nurture my gift I would lose it.

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Josh and Athena, the interview continuing.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: She said other people could waste their time but I didn’t have the right. (beat) I had a calling.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SCENE
dialogues.text: Josh and Athena still driving.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I’m surprised this dairy farmer didn’t just put the cow down.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He could have, but what if the rest of his herd had the same problem?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: So he calls a paranormal consultant before he calls a vet?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: A vet might report the cow’s symptoms to the Department of Agriculture. They could quarantine his farm.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Rock and a hard place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a lot of our clients. They have a problem they can’t go public with so they go online, look for help. Eventually they find us.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Speaking of somebody who needs help, what’s up with Collin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collin driving, brooding.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Collin was a grad student in physics, top of his class.

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: A manic Collin working at his laptop, surrounded by stack textbooks, complicated charts and diagrams.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He wrote his thesis on a variation of the big bang theory that included a race of cybernetic aliens.

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Collin yelling at his PROFESSOR, then ripping a page out his THESIS and eating it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When his professor demanded revisions, Collin refused, saying he’d eat his thesis before he changed a word of it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: He was booted out of school, humiliating for a guy like him. (beat) He’s got something to prove. Up ahead, they can see the dairy farm. Jim and Ellen wavi

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I think we're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, Athena and Collin meeting Jim and Ellen.  10.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Mr. Keeling? I’m Jim Crowley and this is my wife, Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Please call me Josh. These are my associates, Athena Ortiz and Collin Clark. Everybody shakes hands. We hear Delila BELLOW.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: That’s Delila.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We need to take a look at her. Ellen notices Collin adjusting the M-PAC.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You’re not going to kill her, are you?

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Oh no, ma’am. This is an M-PAC device. Multi-Purpose Attack and Control. It’s charged with a non- lethal pulse of super-compressed argon gas.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Actually, I thought we’d let Athena take the lead. Collin is put-out. Athena reacts, who me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barn is a mess and full of shadows. Josh and Athena enter. They can hear Delila’s HEAVY BREATHING coming from somewhere in the darkness. Warily, they creep forward.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Josh, I have a confession to make.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I’m a little worried about the bruja thing. I mean I’ve watched my Grandmother a lot but I’ve never actually done stuff on my own. We hear a threatening HUFF. Delila steps into view. Her condition has worsened, she looks truly berserk.  11.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I think you better get started.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I’ll try an incantation from El Salmo de Los Muertos. It's supposed to have a calming effect on animals. Athena holds her hands out, palms up, intones in Spanish:

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Este en la paz apacible tranquilo, ningin dafio vendra a usted, esté en la paz con mi y curaré su dolor. Deje la energia de mi terraplén del coraz6n usted con amor y deje el-- Suddenly, Delila lets out a roaring BELLOW.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I don’t think this is working. Delila paws the ground and charges.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Josh? Josh seems unconcerned, Delila building speed.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Josh?!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Anytime, Collin. Collin appears with the M-PAC and fires. An INVISIBLE PUL warps the air, hits Delila and stops her cold. She stagge Angle on Josh, Athena and Collin as we hear Delila SLUMP the ground. Collin looks at Athena, smug.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Radio Shack. There is no substitute.

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE LATER
dialogues.text: Josh examining the unconscious Delila, Athena taking pict with a digital camera, Jim and Ellen watching.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She’s got no obvious contusions or lacerations, no blood anywhere. Josh uses a mini-lite to check Delila’s eyes.  12.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind my asking, how does a fella get into a field like this?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Started early. I was that kid. (off Delila) Her pupils are dilated but she’s not aphasic.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: That kid? INT. (FLASHBACK) YOUNG JOSH’S ROOM/APARTMENT -- EVENING A chemistry set, models of spaceships hanging on wires, terrariums full of lizards and spiders, a poster of Steph King looming over everything. YOUNG JOSH, 10 years old, reading a comic book with great concentration, stacks of nearby, a PET SNAKE slithering up his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You know, the loner, the oddball, the one everybody called “weirdo”?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SCENE
dialogues.text: Josh checks Delila’s nose and ears.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I was a curious kid too, almost to the point of stupidity. (off Delila) Ears are clean, no discharge or ectoplastic residue.

dialogues.speaker: EXT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh crawling out of an old coal mine, blackened wi soot, sputtering, BATS flying past him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If somebody said Big Foot was living in the old abandoned mine? I'd crawl in there and take a look.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SCENE
dialogues.text: Josh puts a THERMOMETER in Delila’s mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: When I was ten years old I even camped out in the cemetery on Halloween night. I wanted to see a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: How did your folks feel about that?  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh still reading his comic book.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My Mom raised me by herself and she worked nights. Josh's mom, RACHEL enters. Attractive and warm, early thirties, nurses uniform. She’s putting on her coat.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don’t want to go trick or treating?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She never knew and I never told her. Josh checks Delila’s thermometer.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Low grade fever, her tongue is discolored too. I’1ll need a blood sample.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And did you? See a ghost?

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN, (0.8)
dialogues.text: Josh, over here!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I saw a lot of things that night

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Everyone gathered around Collin, kneeling in the wreckage Delila’s stall, a MOUND OF MANURE in front of him. He shi a UV light on the manure illuminating HUNDREDS OF TINY WO

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Worms.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Cows get worms all the time and they don’t act like Delila.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: I found these in Delila’s stall and nowhere else.  14.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I want them collected, Collin. Every single one. Delila stirs, groans.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She’s going to wake up pretty soon. Can we put her someplace secure?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’ve got a breeding corral. We could roll her on to a tarp, drag her in there with the tractor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group comes out.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Do you think she’s possessed?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She’s showing some of the signs; anomalous aggression, preternatural strength -- but the worms, I’m not sure how they fit in. (then) You’ve got to stop selling milk.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Okay, but I can’t do it forever. I’ve got a small operation here.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We'll work as fast as we can and I’ll call you as soon as we know something. Jim and Ellen move off.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: I’ll do a blood panel and full work- up on the worms.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: How come Delila is the only one that got them?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Gut feeling? She was deliberately infected. (to Collin) Make up a separate worm sample for me. I’ll get started at home, see if I can identify them.  15.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: You sure you want to take those things into your house?

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: (patronizing) Worms are cold- blooded. On ice they’ll be inert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh driving, A LITTLE RED COOLER on the seat beside him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Spending Halloween night at the cemetery was one of those things, it seemed like a good idea at the time.

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh seeing Rachel to the door.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You can still change your mind. Mrs. Webberly will take you trick or treating with her kids.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JOSH
dialogues.text: No thanks. I’1ll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'll always wonder how my life would have been different if I'd gone trick or treating with Mrs. Webberly. Josh arrives at his house, turns in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angle on a SHOULDER HOLSTER WITH A GUN IT, hanging over a chair, an LAPD DETECTIVE’S GOLD SHIELD CLIPPED TO THE HOLSTER.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I had a conversation with Bob Fletcher, insurance guy, lives three houses down? New angle: LaSandra moving her new sofa. Ted at the windo watching Josh get out of the car.  16.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: He told me Josh calls himself a paranormal consultant. Whatever that is.

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Really? His wife told me he was a scientist. (beat) Are you going to help me move this sofa?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (helping her) I worked a long time so I could afford this house, so I could get away from noise and pollution and the traffic and most of all? The nutcases.

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Ted --

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: So here I am, in my dream house, mortgaged to the hilt and who is my next door neighbor? A nutcase!

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: You don’t know that, Ted. You don’t know that at all. Now we’re going over there for lunch tomorrow and you're going to behave yourself, you understand? INT. KITCHEN/JOSH’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER Josh crosses, puts the red cooler in the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You'd think it would be a problem, coming home after a day at work, making the transition from the strange and supernatural to the mundane routines of normal life. Adam appears.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Mom and I have a disagreement over certain implied terms and exclusionary clauses. You may be asked to mediate.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.O)
dialogues.text: Actually, I have trouble telling the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, Barbara and Adam having dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: We have a clean slate with Ted and LaSandra and I'd like to keep it that way. As far as they’re concerned we’re a perfectly normal family.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You mean we’re not?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Nobody else in the neighborhood seems to think so.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: If you'd just let me talk about my work it wouldn’t be such a big mystery.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: There’s only so much people can accept, Josh. It’s one thing to say you believe in UFO’s, it’s another thing to say you’ve been on one. DANNI enters. 16 years old, slovenly, not quite cute, poster child for low self-esteem.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hey, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Hey. Danni sits down, starts eating. Barbara shoots a look Josh, then:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You skipped school, Danni?

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Everybody skips school, Dad. It’s like, what you do?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Didn’t your contract stipulate penalties?

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me you signed that stupid thing. 17. a at  They hear 18.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (to Josh) Cal made her skip school.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Cal didn’t make me do anything.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: (to Danni) Mom said I had to sign it or I wouldn’t get my allowance.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: We negotiated, sweetheart. It was give and take.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: So why’d you skip, Danni?

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Cal’s band was rehearsing and he needed me to like, do stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: He treats you like a maid servant.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: He does not!

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (to Josh) She cleans his house, which by the way, is down by the landfill.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Okay, Mom, we get it. You hate my boyfriend, just like you hate everything else about me.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (hurt) Danni! a car ROAR up to the house, the horn HONK.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: That’s Cal. I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I think I need to talk to him. Danni groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Danni come out of the house, cross to the drivew  19.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: (whispers) He’s the first cool boyfriend I’ve ever had. Don’t embarrass me!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don’t embarrass her, like I’m the freak here. They approach a tricked-out ACURA, a guy named CAL in the driver’s seat. 18, unshaven, unwashed, tats, thinks a lot himself. Danni gets in. Josh moves up to the driver’s win

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hey, Cal, how are you? Cal shrugs, too cool.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Listen, we’re a little concerned about Danni skipping school. Cal REVS the engine, drowning out Josh’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s really important that she keep up her attendance -- Cal keeps REVVING the engine, Josh trying to talk over it until finally:

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: We gotta go, Dad! Cal gives Josh a fuck-you sneer and peels out of the driveway. Josh watches after the car, confounded.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.O)
dialogues.text: People ask me all the time. Have the aliens landed? Are they living among us disguised as human beings? (beat) Yes, they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh in bed. Barbara at the dressing table, moisturizing.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? We can’t let her keep seeing him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Telling her not to will only make it worse.  20.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You mean we can’t do anything? We have no control at all?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Speaking of control, don’t you think your contract with Adam is a little much?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: No, he needs clear-cut boundaries.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: And what happens when you’re not around to threaten him with lawsuits? Barbara gets into bed.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: That was exactly your attitude with Danni. Just let her do whatever she wants. Never mind that she doesn’t care about her appearance or her grades or...herself. She puts her head on Josh’s chest, sighs a parents’ sigh.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: How did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Josh kisses her, then turns out the light. JOSH V.O. It’s human nature to try and control your life and the people you love. The mistake is thinking you had any in the first place. We hold here in the darkness. Faintly at first, we hear a odd CRUNCHING SOUND. The camera moves off Josh and Barbar following the sound out of the bedroom and through the ho the crunching getting louder and louder. Now we’re in the kitchen heading towards the fridge, pushing through the d to the little red cooler, then into the cooler itself to CLEAR PLASTIC PETRI DISH, nestled in ice, some WORMS insi

dialogues.speaker: THE WORMS
dialogues.text: They’re eating through the plastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delila in small metal corral. She’s bellowing angrily, ramming the gate with her head. Jim and Ellen watching.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: She’s getting worse, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What the hell are those PCI people doing?! INT. STUDY/JOSH’'S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Josh on the phone with Collin. On his computer screen is PHOTO OF A WORM that looks just like Delila’s worms.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Delila’s worms are just your run-of- the-mill coccidia. No reason they should be causing anything worse than a stomachache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collin on the speakerphone with Josh.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: We've got a bigger problem. Jim Crowley called. Delila is deteriorating fast.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: How did her blood panel come back?

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Negative. It’s not an infection, drugs or toxicity.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Which leads us back to the worms.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: (grudging) Athena has a theory. Athena appears alongside Collin. She has a large, antique BOOK; the leather cover crumbling, pages yellow with age.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I had a chat with my Grandmother, Josh. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ATHENA (cont'd) She said the worms reminded her of something she heard about, something to do with an Indian tribe called the Michaguas. I found them in one of her books. As Athena continues we FLASH TO PRIMITIVE DRAWINGS in the book appropriate to her narration.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: The Michaguas lived in Peru about the time Columbus sailed for America. They used insects in their religious ceremonies; hornets, scorpions, army ants -- and worms.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: The high priests extracted the worms from the stomachs of their most ferocious bulls and then performed a blood rite, basically, black magic, which transformed the worms into pequefios demonios, or little demons.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Oh please --

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: The worms were fed to the dairy cattle and then their milk was given to the tribe’s warriors just before a big battle. It made them super-aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: And Delila is acting like a super- aggressive bull. (then) What happened to the dairy cattle?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: The worms made them so crazy the priests eventually had to kill them.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Doesn’t bode well for Delila.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s suppose Delila’s worms are somehow related to your ferocious-bull-black-magic-demon- worms. How does that help us? Jim said he might have to put Delila down.  23.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s a point. (beat) So let’s skip the diagnostics for now and find a way to kill the worms. Try commercial de-wormers first.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: I’m on it. They hang up. We stay with Josh, thinking...

dialogues.speaker: EXT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh looking out of the window. Below, he can see Rachel emerge from the building, clusters of KIDS in Halloween costumes moving past her. She stops, looks up a him and waves. He waves back.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’ll always remember my Mom’s face that night. In a way, it was the last time I’d see it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh comes out of the building wearing his backpack He looks to see that Rachel is really gone, then runs off the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the present. Barbara arranging potato chips on a platter in a precise pattern, Adam bringing a bowl of cre SOUR CREAM DIP out of the fridge. We catch a glimpse of t red cooler.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I’ll tell you what, if you help me serve snacks to Ted and LaSandra? We'll forego 14B and 14C and use the ad-interim clause to credit you with compliance.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: I accept. Barbara takes the bowl of dip from Adam and sets it in th center of the platter.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: There, that’s perfect. We hear Cal’s Acura ROAR up to the house and then the HOR honk. Barbara stiffens, can’t stand that sound.  24. INT. HALLWAY/JOSH’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS Danni comes out of her room, responding to the HORN. As s starts down the hall, Josh comes out of the study. They s look at each other, Josh perplexed, Danni defensive.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You could do so much better, Danni.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Actually, Dad, I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Your Mom is right about him. He's a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Mom doesn’t care. She just doesn’t want me to embarrass her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: That’s not true at all. The phone in Josh’s study RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I have to get that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: So get it. She walks past him and exits.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOSH'S HOUSE-- SAME DAY
dialogues.text: Cal sitting in the Acura, HONKING the horn. A HAND REACHE INTO FRAME and takes the key out of the ignition. New angle: Barbara, standing at the driver’s side window, keys in hand. Cal sneers.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: What’s up, Barb?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Call me Mrs. Keeling and if you’re going to pick up my daughter the least you could do is knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: I’m not really into knocking.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: And from now on you will not bring Danni home after her curfew and you will not make her skip school.  25.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, here’s the thing, Barb. (beat) Danni’s s my bitch now and there’s nothing you can do about it. Barbara’s jaw drops. Cal takes his keys back as Danni get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Let’s go already. Cal cackles and peels out of the driveway. INT. KITCHEN/JOSH’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER Barbara enters, furious, beside herself.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Danni’s my bitch?! Danni’s my bitch?!! She tries to calm down but can’t. Impulsively, she grabs chip off the perfect platter, takes a big scoop of sour c dip and shoves it in her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collin working with chemicals, muttering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Collin? Angle on Athena looking into the industrial fridge. She h up two empty PETRI DISHES, tiny holes chewed through them

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: What happened to the worms? INT. STUDY/JOSH’'S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Josh on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What do you mean the worms escaped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collin and Athena on the speakerphone with Josh.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: I mean they chewed through the polystyrene petri dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're inside the industrial fridge, the worms squiggling of holes they’ve made in the petri dishes. They crawl on the fridge rack...

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Their reaction to the cold was to seek a warmer temperature but once they escaped the dishes they still had to get out of the fridge. The worms traveling along the bars of the rack. They’re s tiny the distances from their perspective are enormous.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Long way to go if you’re a worm.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Exactly. And that’s why they decided to generate their own heat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Sex, of course. But they needed the proper environment, the chemical equivalent of soft lighting and a Luther VanDross CD. ».-the worms stop, raise their heads, look around...

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: In their case it was free glucose, acid triglycerides, casein proteins, lactose and --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Collin --

dialogues.speaker: RESUME COLLIN AND ATHENA
dialogues.text: looking into the open industrial fridge. A CARTON OF COTT CHEESE, A BOX OF YOGURT AND A QUART OF MILK are all bubbl over with froth and worms.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Anything made with milk. Cottage cheese, yogurt, ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Josh, didn’t you take some worms home with you? And weren’t they in petri dishes?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the dishes were in a cooler. (realizes) Also made of polystyrene. Just then, Josh catches a momentary glimpse of Barbara crossing the hall. She’s walking backwards.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’ll call you back. INT. KITCHEN/JOSH’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER Josh rushes in, starts to open the fridge but sees the platter of chips on the counter, chips missing, scoop mar in the sour cream dip. He takes a closer look. The dip is moving.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh no! The doorbell RINGS. EXT. JOSH'S HOUSE -- A MOMENT LATER. Ted and LaSandra are there, Ted with a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Remember, behave yourself.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s not me you need to worry about. The door opens, Josh frazzled but covering.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Ted! LaSandra! Nice to see you! What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Barbara invited us for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (beat) Right, yes, lunch! (then) Why don’t you guys go on in the living room and make yourselves comfortable. I‘1ll see what’s keeping Barb. INT. BEDROOM/JOSH’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER Josh enters, sees Barbara, sitting at the dressing table her slip. She’s unnervingly still.  28.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Honey? (mo response) Honey, are you okay? Josh moves closer, sees Barbara’s reflection in the mirro blank, bovine expression on her face. She’s looking at he MAKEUP ITEMS like she’s never seen them before.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Have to..get ready...

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just stay put for now? I‘’ll be back in a second. INT. LIVING ROOM/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Adam is serving the platter of chips and dip to Ted and LaSandra.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Help yourself. It’s Mom’s famous onion sour cream dip.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Why thank you, young man. Don’t mind if I do. Ted takes a chip, starts to scoop up some dip when the wh platter is snatched away! New angle: Josh with the platter.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This is not for you! I mean, this is not for anybody...people I mean. These are, um, doggie treats.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: We have a dog?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I'll get the real snacks.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: When did we get a dog? Josh turns, stops short. Barbara standing in the doorway, dress on backwards, hair half-combed, make-up smeared.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Barb! Honey! Gosh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she okay?  29.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, she’s fine. On Josh, covering his alarm...

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh, apprehensive, following a narrow trail.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I took a shortcut to the cemetery but it was still a long walk. Young Josh comes out of the trees and on to the crest of hill. There’s a sweeping view of the CEMETERY; row upon r of headstones, crypts and mausoleums. The sun is going do

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I wasn’t scared. Well, not a lot. I mean let’s suppose I saw a ghost? What was it going to do, eat me? INT. DINING ROOM/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Back to the present. Josh, Barbra, LaSandra and Ted havin lunch, everyone trying not to notice Barbara. She’s sniff her pasta salad.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: So how did you two meet?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: On the job. I’m a detective, LaSandra’s a psychologist. I consulted her on a case and it was love at first sight.

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: (teasing) For him, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: She tries to play it off but she was all over me. Barbara picks up her fork, sniffs that too.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (covering) Are you guys planning a family?

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: That’s one of the reasons we moved here. Seemed like the ideal place.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Quiet, peaceful, the people are just ordinary folks.  30. Barbara reaches over to LaSandra’s plate, takes the PARSL GARNISH, puts it in her mouth, chews languidly.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (covering) Barb’s a vegetarian. Loves anything green.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m a meat man myself. Yeah, gimme a big ol’ bloody hunk of beefsteak anytime. Offended, Barbara looks at him and bellows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted comes storming out, LaSandra following.

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Where are you going?!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m going to get my badge and my gun and then I’m going back in there and haul those two nutcases to jail! She grabs him, turns him around.

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Stop it, Ted! You can’t arrest them for being nut -- you can’t arrest them!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Well I am not living next door to people that serve doggie treats, and make animal noises!

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Yes, I know, it was strange.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Did you see Barbara? She had her dress on backwards! That’s not strange, that’s crazy!

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: I think they’re having some kind of family crisis. If we just give them some time to work through it I’m sure they'll be fine.  31.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Well they better be fine. They better be damn fine! EXT. CAL’S PLACE -- SAME DAY A ramshackle two-story house. Cal and his BAND MEMBERS sitting on the porch, throwing back beers.

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER 1
dialogues.text: If we’re gonna party tonight we need booze money.

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER 2
dialogues.text: I’m tapped out.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER 3
dialogues.text: What about your scrag? Angle on Danni, in the yard, washing Cal’s car.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: I'll find out. She’s gotta be good for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam frightened. Through the pass-through he can see into the dining room and living room. Barbara is meandering around, bellowing and knocking things over, gradually los her mind. EXT. BACKYARD/JOSH'’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY A frantic Josh, talking on his CELL with one hand and inexplicably MOWING THE LAWN with the other.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: This is Josh. Barbara ate some worms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collin and Athena on the speaker phone with Josh.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Barbara did what?!

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Oh my God!  32.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We need a de-wormer, Collin.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: The commercial ones don’t work! I’ve tried them all. The worms don’t even react!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Then formulate one yourself. I'm on my way.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Right! They disconnect, we _stay with Collin and Athena. Collin starts bustling around, gathering chemicals and muttering himself. Athena thinks a bit, then grabs her jacket and exits the office.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME JOSH
dialogues.text: taking the GRASS CATCHING BAG off the lawn mower. He rush towards the house with it as Adam comes out.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Dad! What’s wrong with Mom?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She’s not feeling well, Adam. Josh hurries past Adam and into the house. INT. DEN/JOSH'’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Barbara lumbering around, huffing and grunting and bangin into things. She stops, smells something, sniffs loudly. We follow her following her nose through various rooms an then into the hallway to an open door. She looks inside. Stairs lead down to the basement. Piled on the cement flo is an inviting MOUND OF FRESHLY MOWN GRASS. Barbara huffs approvingly. She descends the stairs, and the door slams shut behind her! INT. HALLWAY/JOSH’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS Josh has just shut the door, Adam looking on. Immediately we hear Barbara trying to get out but Josh jams a HOCKEY STICK between the door and the opposite wall, wedging it closed.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: You’re locking Mom in the basement?  33.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Just for a little while, until she feels better! INT. BASEMENT/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Barbara still trying to get out. She hears VOICES, bounds down the stairs, crosses to a narrow transom (too narrow escape) that’s just above ground level. Through it she ca see Josh and Adam come out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh moving quickly to his car, Adam trailing.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: What’s going on, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s a long story, Adam. T’ll explain it to you later.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Where are you going?!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: To the office. He stops, kneels, takes Adam by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Now listen to me closely. Don’t go in the kitchen, don’t eat anything, and whatever you do, don’t let Mom out of the basement, do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: But Dad --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You’re in charge while I’m gone, Adam. I’m counting on you. Josh gets in his car and drives away. On Adam, alone and afraid.

dialogues.speaker: EXT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: It’s dark now. Young Josh drinking a chocolate milk throu a straw. Finished, he puts the empty carton into his backpack and surveys the cemetery. It’s quiet and still. Disappointed, he sighs, stands up, puts on his backpack.. »..and then a DARK SHAPE glides silently out of the trees nearby.  34. Young Josh freezes, watches the shape move through the ai effortlessly as a bird carried on the wind, swooping in circles around the cemetery and then descending, landing silently on the ground. It’s a WITCH, young, gaunt, flowi robe, piercing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CU YOUNG JOSH
dialogues.text: stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collin is conducting an experiment. THE BOX OF WORMY COTT CHEESE we saw before is enclosed in a large AQUARIUM.  35. At either end of the aquarium are TWO ELECTRONIC DEVICES look like modified radar guns. A BEAM is shining from one device to the other, passing through the cottage cheese. Both devices are humming, indicator lights flashing. Josh bursts in, crosses quickly to Collin.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Where are we?!

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: I’m trying to kill the worms electromagnetically without hurting any cellular structures around it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: So the cottage cheese is Barbara?

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Yes. The question is, will the worms die and leave Bar -- the cottage cheese intact. Collin turns dials and pushes buttons, the humming gets louder, the lights more intense, the worms squiggling.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: They’re reacting... The cottage cheese EXPLODES, covering the inside of the aquarium, muck shooting up to the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delila still ramming the gate on the breeding stall, weakening it, Jim and Ellen watching, worried.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What happens if she gets out of there, Jim? They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim enters, crosses to a gun rack and finds a DEER RIFLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Collin staring at the aquarium mess.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s okay. This is all my fault.  36. Athena enters, excited.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: I have something! Athena shows them a small APOTHECARY BOTTLE. She opens it spills what looks like a FINE, UNIFORM GRAVEL into her ha

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Laccophilia Hydrolatus. A parasitic beetle. They're dehydrated.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Dehydrated beetles?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: The Laccophilia live in the desert and during the dry times they burrow underground and basically hibernate. They can stay that way for years, and then when the rains come, they rehydrate and come back to life.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Where did you get them?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: An herbalist in Chinatown. My grandmother's boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: The Laccophilia will eat the worms.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: They do this in commercial agriculture. Introduce one parasite to get rid of another.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: But if the Laccophilia are inside a living body, won’t they propagate? Won’t we just be replacing the worms with Laccophilia?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: They have a short life cycle, a few hours, and these are just males.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: How can you tell?  37.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Because they’re wearing little jock straps -- that’s what the herbalist told me!

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: But you said worms are demonized. Won't they be resistant to ordinary Laccophilia?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: They’re demonized too. Me, the herbalist and my grandmother did a little ritual on them.

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Athena, ATHENA’S GRANDMOTHER and an ELDELRY CHINESE HERBA performing a ritual over the apothecary bottle, making strange movements, chanting in Chinese and Spanish, incen burning.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: The herbalist is a heavy dude.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Is this something like what you did in the barn with Delila?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Could we just try it please?! INT. BASEMENT/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Barbara, growling as she tries to shoulder down the door it won’t budge. Defeated, she descends the steps to the basement floor and snarls in frustration. Then she hears something, FOOTSTEPS coming from above. She tracks the so with her eyes. INT. DEN/JOSH’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS Adam crossing, plunking down in front of the TV. He watch for a bit, and then he hears Barbara, an unsettling bovin thrum in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Adammmm....oh Adammmmmmm... On Adam, uh-oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Athena, Josh and Collin gathered around a tall BEAKER OF WATER. Athena adds the dried Laccophilia to the water.  38.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Rehydrate the Laccophilia... The Laccophilia drift down in the water, gradually coming alive as they descend. They look like tiny tadpoles.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: They’re coming to life! Athena puts some worms in the beaker.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Versus Delila’s worms...

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: The presence of the worms excites the Laccophilia. They swirl around the worms and start savagely consuming them.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: They're like piranhas. They’re eating the worms alive!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: But will the same thing happen inside a living body? This is my wife we’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Yes, they could very well attack the tissue around them and eat Barbara’s stomach lining or chew through her intestines or -- (off Josh’s look) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We'll have to test it on Delila.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: You guys pack up. I'll get the van.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Athena? (she hesitates) Nice work. Athena smiles and rushes out. The guys start gathering th equipment they’ll need. Collin stops, looks at Josh.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Is this why you hired a witch? This kind of situation?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I hired her for a lot of reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Josh, still watching the Witch. She’s standing on a crypt, staring off into the night sky, waiting. And now another WITCH comes gliding into view, landing near the first. Then ANOTHER comes walking through the headstones, and then ANOTHER sails into view...and then ANOTHER...and then ANOTHER...a coven. INT. DEN/JOSH'’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Back to the present. Adam has a pillow over his head. He' trying to shut out the sound of his mother’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Adammmm?...Aaaadammm....mommy is calling youuuuu....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, Collin and Athena, Josh driving fast. His cell RING He answers:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s Jim. Delila’s going to get out of the stall. I’ve got to shoot her!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No, don’t shoot her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim talking on his CELL, watching Delila ramming the stal gate, the hinges giving way.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’ve got neighbors with kids! If somebody gets hurt --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: If you shoot her we can’t test the Laccophilia!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Test the what? Delila gets her horns interlocked in the gate, gives it a mighty shake. The hinges snap, the gate about to come off

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: She’s getting out! Jim drops his cell, grabs the deer rifle...  40.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOSH
dialogues.text: yelling into his cell.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Don’t shoot her! Don’t shoot her! From the cell he hears: BANG! BANG!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh no --

dialogues.speaker: RESUME DAIRY FARM
dialogues.text: Ellen is driving the TRACTOR towards the stall, the motor BACKFIRING (the bangs) As Delila pushes the gate down, th tractor pushes it back in place and holds it there, Delil held in for now. Elated, Jim waves his hat.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yeee-ha! That’s my girl! Ellen beams. Jim picks up his cell.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: We're okay. We didn’t shoot her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Thank, God! INT. UPSTAIRS BEDROOM/CAL’S PLACE -- SAME DAY Apres sex. Danni on the raggedy futon, blanket pulled up around her. Cal in his underwear, going through the pocke of her jeans.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: I don’t have more money, Cal. I spent it on gas for your car!

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: We gotta buy booze for the party. Frustrated, Cal throws her jeans at her. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: What about your parents?

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: XCU
dialogues.text: liquid filled, swimming with Laccophilia.  41. New angle. Collin loading the dart into the M-PAC; Josh, Athena, Jim and Ellen looking on.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Collin aims at Delila and fires. The dart whizzes through the air and sticks in her haunch. She bellows.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We wait.

dialogues.speaker: EXT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh watching the coven of Witches. There are about dozen of them, in their 20’s and 30’s, not hideous-lookin but a witchly gleam in their eyes. They’re doing a strang dance, circling around a crypt. One of them makes some especially wild gyrations, her face revealed in a shaft o moonlight. It’s Rachel, Josh’s Mom.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JOSH
dialogues.text: Mom! Shocked and terrified, Young Josh stumbles back, loosenin some rocks which roll down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: THE WITCHES
dialogues.text: react to the sound, stop their dancing, alerted. One of them sees an indiscernible figure (Young Josh) retreating into the treeline. She points, lets out an ungodly SCREEC

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: The Witches chase Young Josh through the dark woods, howl and caterwauling. As the sequence concludes, Young Josh arrives at the edge of a SWAMP. He looks back, can see th Witches coming. He thinks a moment, then picks up a ROCK throws it, skipping it across the water.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: The Witches arrive at the edge of the swamp. They can see the RIPPLES in the water left by the skipping rock. They move off in that direction but Rachel remains, looking around, sensing something. Panning down, we can see Josh underwater, face up, pinching his nose and breathing via straw he was using to drink the chocolate milk. He’s look right at Rachel. On his terrified eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the present.  42.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know you’re out there Adam and I’m going to keep calling you and calling you and calling you... INT. BASEMENT/JOSH’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS Barbara at the door, talking relentlessly. She’s struggli to stay in control of herself, rage growing, her voice an octave lower.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: -..and if I have to do this all night and all the next day and all the next night I’ll keep going and I’ll never stop calling you until you open this --

dialogues.speaker: ADAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. HALLWAY/JOSH’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS A worn down Adam at the basement door.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Adam, let me out.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Dad said not to.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Mommy doesn’t want to be locked in the basement, Adam.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: But Dad said --

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Open this door right now! Adam dithers, then starts to remove the hockey stick brac the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: That’s a good boy, Adam! Adam stops, something occurring to him.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Mom?  43.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (very tight) Yes...sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: This is sort of like my allowance.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Your allowance?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, I wanted my allowance just like you want to get out of the basement.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Adammm --

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Maybe we should negotiate. You know, give and take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, Athena, Collin, Jim and Ellen, watching Delila gradually become quieter...and calmer...and then her eyes return to normal.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Will you look at that! Jim approaches Delila, reaches out, scratches her head. S huffs contentedly. Jim is too moved to speak. Ellen hugs Josh, Athena and Collin in turn.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Thank you! MThank you all so much!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We have to go. INT. BASEMENT/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME NIGHT Barbara, on the verge of losing it, listening to Adam.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And in the second paragraph where it says “Adam will pick up his toys on a daily basis”? I want to amend that to say, “Mom will pick up Adam's toys on a daily basis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. HALLWAY/JOSH’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS Adam reading his contract.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: »..and in the section on bicycle care? I'd like “regular maintenance to be performed by Adam” to read “regular maintenance to be performed by Mom”.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: (explodes) LET ME OUTTTTTT!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and LaSandra eating dinner. They hear Barbara yelling

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What are they doing over there?!

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Try not to listen to it, Ted. Just eat your steak. INT. BASEMENT/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME NIGHT Barbara still at the door, roaring at Adam.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: IF YOU DON’T LET ME OUT OF HERE

dialogues.speaker: ADAM OS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mom. I’m not going to negotiate in an atmosphere of intimidation. Barbara starts to respond but hears a car ROAR up to the house. She descends the stairs, crosses to the transom. S can see the Acura in the driveway, Danni and Cal inside, yelling at her, Danni about to cry. Barbara snarls. INT. FOYER/JOSH’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER Danni enters, is met by Adam.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Where’s Mom and Dad?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Dad went out, Mom’s in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: What’s she doing in the basement? Following them through the house.  45.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: She’s acting really nuts! She's been yelling and screaming and breaking stuff and -- Danni stops, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: You’ll understand this when you’re like, older? It’s a girl-thing, it’s called PMS. (beat) Stop following me, okay? Go watch TV or something. INT. BEDROOM/JOSH’S HOUSE -- MOMENTS LATER Danni enters furtively, sees BARBARA’S HANDBAG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PCI van zooms past camera. INT. BASEMENT/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME NIGHT Barbara at the transom, watching Danni cross from the hou back to the Acura. She gets in, gives Cal some money. Cal is disappointed with the amount. He yells at her, throws bills in her face, then peels out of the driveway. Barbara bellows, goes into a mindless rage, knocking thin over, dumping out boxes and bins until something clatters the cement floor. A CROWBAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and LaSandra watching TV. They hear a POUNDING sound. They try to ignore it but the sound continues.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: There’s only so much of this I’m gonna take. INT. BASEMENT/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME NIGHT Barbara working on the door with the crowbar; savagely pounding and prying at the wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam watching the door get shredded, knows he’s in troubl

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: You know what, Mom? We could leave the contract the same!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PCI van in suburbia now, speeding past camera.
Ted and LaSandra still trying to watch TV, the POUNDING sounds from next door continuing.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That’s it. Enough is enough!

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Don’t get involved over there, Ted. Just call the police.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I am the police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted comes out, crosses towards Josh’s house, LaSandra to him.

dialogues.speaker: LASANDRA
dialogues.text: Be careful, Ted! The PCI van pulls into the driveway. Josh jumps out, to his front door, blocking Ted’s path.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Ted! What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s your house, Josh, how the hell would I know?! Josh hears the POUNDING.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh that? Yeah, we’re having a little work done on the house. The door opens, Adam there, crying.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: Mommy’s got a crowbar!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (at Josh) Mommy’s got a crowbar?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She’s a real do-it-yourselfer.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Get outta my way! calling rushes  47. Ted barges past him into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted moving through the house, Josh and Adam trailing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Don’t you need a warrant to come in here, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Not if I have probable cause that a crime is being committed and Lord knows I have that! They arrive at the basement door. It’s completely demolished. A trail of destruction leads away from them, down the hall to the open back door. Barbara’s gone. Ted glares at Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (wanly) She probably went out for some air.

dialogues.speaker: END ACT 3
dialogues.text: AcT 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BUS DRIVER brings the bus to a halt, opens the door. PASSENGERS get aboard, dropping money in the receptacle a they pass. Someone goes by without paying.

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Miss? You have to pay the -- The Bus Driver looks in the rearview mirror, sees TWO MOL ORBS. Barbara’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Never mind.
Josh driving around the neighborhood, looking for Barbara Adam in the shotgun seat, Athena and Collin in the back.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: She didn’t say anything about where she was going?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: No. Favoring Athena and Collin. She glances at him, can still chagrined about the way things have unfolded. gestures at the M-PAC.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: You know, I was thinking, maybe you could teach me how to use that sometime.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Sure. Okay. (then) That was really interesting, what you did with the Laccophilia and the worms?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: The notion of a ritualistic transmutation is very intriguing although I still think there might be a biochemical explanation. I hope you’re open to discussing it.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Anytime, Collin. On Athena, smiling to herself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAL'S PLACE
dialogues.text: A loud drunken party in progress. A self-conscious moving through the CROWD, everyone older than her. one of the Band Members.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Have you seen Cal around?

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER 1
dialogues.text: (mocking) Have you seen Cal around? On Danni, resuming her search... see he’s She Danni She finds  49.

dialogues.speaker: EXT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh, sopping wet and terrified running down the street. He arrives at his apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I ran all the way home...

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh staggers in, rips off his wet clothes and gets into bed. He huddles there, trembling.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Had my Mother seen me? What would she say? What would she do? (beat) Did I still have a mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the present. Josh and the group still driving aro looking for Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: »..-Mom was really mad and screaming and everything, and then when Danni came back she got super-mad.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Danni came back?

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: With that guy, and then they left again. That was when Mom really went ballistic.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (realizes) She wouldn’t...

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: What, Josh?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Barbara hates Danni’s boyfriend, a guy named Cal. (trying to remember) She told me where he lived --

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: You think she went after him?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (remembers) The landfill! She said he lived near the landfill!  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long shot of Cal’s place perched on the edge of the landfill, a vast crater.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRS/CAL'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Danni comes up the stairs, reaches the second floor hallw

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Cal? Are you up here? She moves down the hall to a door, opens it... INT. BEDROOM/CAL’S PLACE -- CONTINUOUS Danni enters.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Cal? She stops abruptly. Cal and a GIRL are on the futon makin out, a BOTTLE OF VODKA on the floor next to them. Danni i mortified. Cal looks at her, sneers.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: You are such a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Close the door and get out.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Fine, just give me my booze back! Danni crosses, grabs the vodka. Cal grabs her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Drop it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I’m outta here. The Girl gets up and exits.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Let go of the bottle, Danni.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: It’s mine, I paid for it!  51. Danni tries to yank free but he’s too strong, standing up while he twists her wrist, bringing her to her knees. She cries out in pain.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Let go or I’ll break your arm! A shadow falls over them. Barbara in the doorway. Cal sneers.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: What’s up, Barb? Barbara steps forward. She’s completely berserk, enraged, demonized.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Mom? She walks towards Cal, her voice like the growl of a beas

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Call..me...Mrs..Keeling!! Barbara gives him a two-hand shove in the chest. He's knocked backwards, hits the wall hard. She catches him on the rebound and slings him into the dresser, smashing it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Mom? Cal tries to get up but Barbara puts a foot on the side o his head, mashing him into the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You little punk! You and your car and your tattoos and your band!

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: Get off me! Get off me you freakin’ old hag!

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Oh I see. A potty mouth. INT. BATHROOM/CAL’S PLACE -- MOMENTS LATER Barbara is holding Cal’s head in the toilet while he flai futilely, Danni watching, aghast, but digging it.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You think I hate you, Danni?! I gave birth to you! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARBARA (cont'd) I worry about you and wish for you and want for you and ache for you and breathe for you every single minute of every single day! I AM

dialogues.speaker: YOUR MOTHERRRR
dialogues.text: Danni is awed by her mother’s tirade but notices:

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: Mom? I don’t think he’s moving. Barbara yanks the sputtering Cal out of the toilet. She p him close, looks him right in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: So tell me something, Cal. (beat) Who's the bitch now?! INT. BEDROOM/CAL’S PLACE -- MOMENTS LATER Barbara bum-rushing Cal out of the bathroom, across the r through the french doors, Danni trailing.

dialogues.speaker: DANIELL
dialogues.text: Mom, don’t! EXT. BALCONY/CAL’S PLACE -- CONTINUOUS Barbara brings Cal to the railing, starts to heave him ov A 200 foot drop to the bottom of the landfill.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: So long, asshole!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Barbara! Barbara hesitates, sees Josh, Adam, Collin (with the M-PA and Athena down below but off to one side(ground level). They've just come around the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (to Collin) Go on up there, get ready to dart her. Collin moves off.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Don’t do it, Barb! He’s had enough. Barbara snarls, not willing to let Cal go.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You've made your point, honey. Hasn’t she Cal?  53.

dialogues.speaker: CAL
dialogues.text: (blubbering) Oh yes! Yes she has! I swear, Mrs. Keeling ma’am! Barbara bellows defiantly, starts to turn Cal over the railing.

dialogues.speaker: NOOOOOO
dialogues.text: But Barbara stops. New angle: Danni has put a hand on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: (tearful) It’s okay, Mom. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: I love you too. Danni hugs her. Barbara’s rage softens, turns into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs Danni...and lets go of Cal. He plummets, screami like a girl, hitting the landfill and disappearing into t sea of garbage. PHLOOOF!! Everyone except Barbara wincing the sound.

dialogues.speaker: INT., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: Young Josh enters. Rachel is at the counter, making a bag lunch, humming, everything normal. She notices him. He tries to control his fear.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Good morning, Josh. Sleep okay?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JOSH
dialogues.text: Yeah. I slept fine.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What did you do last night?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh, the usual stuff, you know.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Want some breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No thanks. I’m supposed to get to school early. Hockey practice.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, here’s your lunch.  54. She gives him his bag lunch. They look at each other a lo beat, Josh trying to see something in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t realize it then, but that Halloween night was my very first case. Rachel smiles warmly, kisses him on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: See you later. Following Young Josh out of the kitchen, down the hall to front door.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was also the start of my career, when a kid’s curiosity became a calling. I had to find out, what's really going on here? Young Josh starts to exit but glances back. Rachel is standing at the sink, staring out of the window at the sk He looks at her, wondering.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So what was my Mom doing in the cemetery that night? I still don’t know, but the case isn’t closed.. »..-not by a long shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the present. Josh comes out, heads towards his newspaper on the lawn. He sees Ted, doing the same.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hey, Ted. Listen, about what happened...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m not havin’ it, Josh. Are you hearing me? I’m not havin’ it. Ted points a finger at Josh, then turns and walks into hi house. On Josh, breathing a weary sigh. INT. STUDY/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Josh on the phone with an official from the US Department Agriculture. Intermittently, we hear a loud GRINDING SOUN  55.

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL 1, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can assure you, Mr. Keeling, we here at the Department of Agriculture monitor the country’s milk supply very carefully --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I wasn’t suggesting --

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL 1, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- and we've received no reports of contaminated milk or cattle displaying the symptoms you describe.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No reports at all?

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Not one. (beat) But you say this particular cow was affected by worms?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What kind of worms?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Well, they were a garden-variety coccidia but they were demonized.

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL 1, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Demon worms?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Yes. The GRINDING SOUND is distracting.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Could you hold on for just a second? INT. ADAM’S ROOM/JOSH’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS The source of the GRINDING SOUND. Adam and Barbara are feeding the pages of his contract into a SHREDDER.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME JOSH
dialogues.text: closing the his study door, picking up the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.  56.

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL 1, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That’s okay. Listen, I’ve got somebody else on the line with me whose more familiar with this kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh great.

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL 2, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Keeling? Yeah, My name’s Jerry Cooper. I’m the supervisor here at the USDA’s Demon Worm and Goblin Grasshopper Department? Josh realizes they’re messing with him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Listen, I know how this sounds --

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL 2, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: No, no, we think you're really on to something here. In fact, we’re sending a crack team of agents to your house right now.

dialogues.speaker: USDA OFFICIAL 1, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You'll recognize them by their big shoes. They put the worms on the sidewalk and stomp on ‘em! The Officials burst into hysterics. Josh hangs up. INT. LIVING ROOM/JOSH’S HOUSE -- SAME DAY Josh and Barbara snuggling on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I’m fine. (off his look) Really. Oh I have the occasional urge to graze but other than that --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I was afraid I was going to lose you. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I know you are...but I have to admit, it wasn’t all bad.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cal, hysterical and blubbering, driving on a desert highw really fast. He whips past a sign that says: LEAVING THE

dialogues.speaker: RESUME JOSH AND BARBARA
dialogues.text: the conversation continuing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I think it’s going to take awhile to patch things up with Ted and LaSandra.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: I’ll talk to LaSandra. (bright idea) I’ll tell her I had the flu.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (not hopeful) Yeah, that might work. Danni enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hey, kiddo. Reveal Danni’s companion. A very butch girl named RITA.

dialogues.speaker: DANNI
dialogues.text: This is my friend Rita. We'll be in my room. Danni and Rita move off. On Josh and Barbara, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Department of Agriculture guys weren’t very receptive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, Athena and Collin, a discussion in progress.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: ...-but that’s not what bothered me. (beat) They said they haven’t received any reports about contaminated milk or possessed cows.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: But isn’t that good?  58.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Think about it. Somebody gave demonized worms to one cow.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Right. Why not a hundred cows or a thousand?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: And why here, why not in Wisconsin, the Dairy State? Why pick a place that’s less than an hour’s drive from this office?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Are you saying --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Just hear me out, okay? Somebody feeds Delila a handful of hay contaminated with the worms. Then Delila shows symptoms that defy explanation so Jim goes online and looks for help. Chatrooms, message boards, that kind of thing. What kind of response would he get?

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: Oh, the usual palaver from the uninformed but anybody who knows anything would refer him to you.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Especially here in my own backyard.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: You mean you were supposed to get the case?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: And take the worm samples. It’s standard operating procedure.

dialogues.speaker: COLLIN
dialogues.text: So what happened to Barbara --

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Was meant for me. Us. It was only by chance we didn’t eat or drink anything that was contaminated.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: But who would want to set us up?  59.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don’t know, but they had to be able to demonize the worms..this wasn’t just anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, asleep in his rocker, the TV on.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Somebody once said, the only normal people are the ones you don’t know very well... New angle. Ellen, standing in the doorway, looking at him Her farm wife demeanor is gone, replaced with a whole oth persona; confident, mysterious, a little menacing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: »..and how many people do you know that well? I mean really? Music begins. The Talking Heads sing “Once In A Lifetime” continuing over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen comes out of the house, moves off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: walking through the countryside, completely at ease in th dark. As the sequence concludes she goes through a DILAPIDATED WOODEN GATE, stops. Reverse angle: We're in a small, neglected GRAVEYARD, overgrown with weeds. Rachel is there, middle-aged now, still attractive, wearing regular clothes. The two women look at each other, smile.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: We tried.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: And we’ll try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel and Ellen are doing the same witches dance Young J Saw on Halloween Night. Pulling back as other middle-aged WOMEN come walking, gliding and flying over the hills and through the fields and out of the night sky, converging o the graveyard....
